title: AETIUS, an eclectic philosopher, author of a compilation of the views of earlier Greek thinkers, the pre-Socratic portion of which is based ultimately on the Opinions of the Natural Philosophers of Theophrastus. Aetius' date is uncertain, but the first century AD is probable
bishop of Ratisbon, and one of the leading theologians of his age. Among his many noteworthy works are the Liber de causis (1254-70) and the Summa theologiae

note: Theophrastus (qv) was his most important student. His works are an important source of quotations from and comment upon the pre-Socratics.
title: APOLLONIUS TYANENSIS, a letter-writer of the first century AD. His Letters have been edited by C.L
ARISTOTLE (384-22 BC), the founder of the Peripatetic school of philosophy, who studied in Plato's Academy
ARIUS DIDYMUS, a doxographer of the first century BC. The extant fragments of his writings are published in Doxographi Graeci

title: The most recent edition of the text is by J.H

DIOGENES LAERTIUS, late second/early third century AD, author of a compendium, The Lives of the Philosophers, which preserves much valuable material. The work is edited by H.S. Long in the Oxford Classical Texts series (Oxford 1964) and is also included in the Loeb Classical Library. While his writing is often trivial, scurrilous gossip, drawn from Hellenistic sources, he none the less preserves what seem to be straightforward and reasonably reliable descriptions of Heraclitean doctrine, following a generally Theophrastean tradition (9.7-11), and 197 Sources and Authorities

note: His Allegoriae (or Quaestiones Homericae) have been edited for the Teubner series by F. Oelmann (Leipzig 1910).

title: a Middle Platonist philosopher of the second century AD who influenced later Neoplatonists, especially Plotinus. The most recent edition of the extant fragments of his works is that of E. des Places, Numenius

note: Berlin 1896-1915). The Fragments have been edited by J. Rendel Harris (Cambridge 1886).
